;中国家长对儿童课外读物含有“暴力、色情”主题表示担忧。

;

;据《法制日报》报道，北京一位姓邹的父亲震惊地发现，一本为他的孩子推荐的书，广告上是“推荐给12岁以下儿童的故事集”，却把性骚扰描绘成一种合法的爱形式。

;

;在一个故事中，一个男孩对一个女孩一见钟情。在多次拒绝后，男主开始跟踪她，骚扰她的熟人，最终诉诸暴力。

;

;当女孩提起诉讼时，男孩在被判刑时，在法庭上挑衅地宣称：“我可能失去了自由，但我永远不会失去对你的爱！”

;

;令人惊讶的是，他的行为感动了女孩，两人最终在法庭上恩爱相拥，从此过上了幸福的生活。

;

; p>;

;这本书用这个故事来宣扬坚持的美德，告诉孩子们只要坚持不懈的努力，最终就会得到想要的结果。

;

;内容让邹先生感到不安，他告诉《法制日报》：“当骚扰被描绘成对爱的顽强追求，这会对12岁以下儿童的价值观产生什么样的影响？”我在网上为四岁女儿购买了一本据称是儿童性教育书籍后，也表示了担忧。

;

;这本书得到了许多书店的大力推荐，并得到了网上销售点的大力推广。

;

;然而，翻了几页后，她发现里面的对话和插图令人难以忍受。

;

;其中一张照片甚至显示一名男子抱着一个小女孩，小女孩的内裤外露，手放在她的私处。

;

;“Un “这本书打着性教育的幌子，只关注性，并没有提供任何积极的教育价值。”赖说。

;

;性在中国传统上是一个禁忌话题，导致全国性教育和素养的匮乏。

;

;最近的女童保护调查数据显示，2020年媒体公开报道的儿童性虐待案件有332起，受害者年龄越来越小，大多数是中小学生。 .

;

;此外，青少年开始恋爱的年龄正在下降，导致随意性行为更加频繁。

;

;2013年，国家卫生健康委员会公布，中国人工流产总数达到惊人的1300万例，为世界之最。

;

;其中一半以上的女性曾多次堕胎，其中近一半的堕胎是在25岁及以下的女性身上进行的。

;

;为了解决这个问题，修订后的未成年人保护法于2021年6月实施，其中规定“学校、幼儿园必须对未成年人进行适龄性教育”。

;据报道，北京最近与西藏流亡精神领袖达赖喇嘛取得了联系，但观察人士表示，重启会谈可能具有挑战性。

;

;达赖喇嘛本月早些时候庆祝了自己的 88 岁生日，他上周表示，中国官员已“正式或非正式”地与他进行了接触。

;

;他没有具体说明沟通的时间或方式。 ，但表示他“总是愿意对话”。

;

;“中国官员现在已经意识到西藏人民的精神非常坚强，因此为了解决西藏问题，他们想与我联系，”十四世达赖喇嘛在印度达兰萨拉告诉记者，他此前在那里建立了西藏流亡政府（TGIE）。他于 2011 年辞去该机构政治负责人的职务。

;

;“我也准备好了”，他说，并补充说，西藏人并不寻求独立，并决定继续作为中华人民共和国的一部分。

;

;西藏自治区政府部长诺津卓玛早些时候曾证实，最近与北京进行了“非官方和非正式”的“秘密渠道沟通”。

;

;她表示，在达赖喇嘛统治期间恢复谈判至关重要。据共同社报道，诺津在访问日本期间表示，“[现任达赖喇嘛]拥有道德权威，他拥有合法性，无论他在世时能提出什么解决方案或解决方案，人们都会给予认可。”

;

;自从反对中国控制的起义失败以来，第十四世达赖喇嘛丹增嘉措已经流亡了 64 年。 1959年的西藏。北京将其TGIE视为分裂组织。

;

;从2002年到2010年，达赖喇嘛代表与中国政府进行了九轮对话，但没有取得什么成果。此后没有举行过正式会议。

;

;中美因西藏人权问题针锋相对的北京制裁2

;

;香港科技大学中国民族政治专家巴里·索特曼表示，随着达赖喇嘛年事已高，无法再环游世界，双方都有理由恢复接触。

;

;“从TGIE的角度来看，他们在国际上的最高牌就是达赖喇嘛， ”他说，并补充说，西藏问题在西方和印度一直以达赖喇嘛为代表，但在过去几年已从西方议程中淡出。

;

;至于北京，萨特曼表示，这次外展的时机可能是因为西方的注意力被俄罗斯入侵乌克兰和新疆人权等其他全球问题转移到了西藏。

;

;“中国政府知道，美国能为西藏流亡者做的事情非常有限。随着达赖喇嘛的形象在西方意识中逐渐淡出，达赖喇嘛的形象很可能会减弱。”他说。

;

;他说，达赖喇嘛关于西藏是中国的一部分且不寻求独立的最新声明与 TGIE 声称西藏是一个被占领的独立国家的说法相矛盾。

;

;“秘密渠道接触可能已经产生了[这个]结果，”他说。

;

;哥伦比亚大学现代西藏研究项目创始人罗伯特·巴尼特表示，如果北京相信的话如果能够以强势地位进行谈判，它可能会要求更多让步，而提供更少回报。因此，他表示，最近的接触努力并不一定表明北京有兴趣立即重启谈判，而是增加了谈判的先决条件。

;

;“这将使西藏方面的事情变得非常困难。”

;

;巴尼特预测，当务之急将是达赖喇嘛的继承或转世问题，并补充说，北京“几乎肯定”希望让达赖喇嘛就中国政府选择达赖喇嘛的最终权力达成一致。另一项要求可能是承认现任北京任命的班禅喇嘛，这是继达赖喇嘛之后的第二位西藏精神领袖。

;

;1995年，双方各指定一名候选儿童为第十一世班禅喇嘛，这一冲突从未得到解决。

;

;为什么布拉德·皮特在1997年的电影《西藏七年》之后被禁止进入中国

;

;中国政府坚称其有权批准这一任命包括达赖喇嘛和班禅喇嘛在内的所有高级藏传佛教人物的遗志，被视为中国皇帝继承的遗产。这一说法遭到了达赖喇嘛及其追随者的强烈反对。

;

;达赖喇嘛表示，他的继任者未来的角色应该由藏人决定，甚至可能在印度找到转世灵童。但中国坚称转世灵童必须遵循严格的仪式和宗教历史。

;

;“为了有机会获得这些，北京必须在达赖喇嘛去世前采取行动，”巴内特说。

;

;“无论如何，当中国方面认为达赖喇嘛处于最虚弱的时候，它总是有可能推动达成协议；这就是强硬谈判者的工作方式，”他说。

;法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙(Emmanuel Macron)的最高外交顾问表示，中国正在向俄罗斯提供可用作军事装备的物品，尽管规模不大。

;

;周四晚些时候在阿斯本安全论坛上被问及西方是否看到任何证据表明中国在乌克兰战争中以任何方式武装俄罗斯时，马克龙爱丽舍宫外交团队负责人埃马纽埃尔·博纳(Emmanuel Bonne)告诉主持人：“是的，有迹象表明他们正在做我们不希望他们做的事情。”

;

;当被问及中国是否正在提供武器时，博纳说：“嗯，某种军事装备……据我们所知，他们没有向俄罗斯提供大规模军事能力，但[我们需要]没有交付。”

;

;法国官员告诉美国有线电视新闻网，博纳指的是军民两用技术和非致命援助，例如头盔和防弹衣。

;

;'P乌廷是复仇的终极使徒：中央情报局称瓦格纳老板将遭到报复

;

;在被要求置评时，白宫国家安全委员会发言人表示，美国官员对中国向俄罗斯转让“两用装备”感到担忧，这些装备可能用于杀死乌克兰人或对战场产生重大影响。

;

;“我们尚未看到中国向俄罗斯转让致命援助用于乌克兰战场，但我们对此保持警惕该官员表示，并继续密切关注。

;

;该官员表示，“我们将继续对为俄罗斯战争提供支持的公司采取行动，无论这些公司的总部位于中华人民共和国还是世界任何地方。”

;

;马克龙办公室没有立即回复路透社的置评请求。中国驻巴黎大使馆没有立即回复通过电子邮件发送的置评请求。

;

;自莫斯科于 2022 年 2 月全面入侵乌克兰以来，中国一再否认向俄罗斯发送军事装备。

;

;博纳很少接受媒体公开采访，但经常向记者介绍背景情况。 4月份法国总统访华期间，他是马克龙外交代表团的成员，也是马克龙与中国高级官员的联络人。

;

;“我们最需要的是中国弃权，”博纳说。 “我们需要他们明白，乌克兰是一场全球规模的冲突，出于原则原因，我们不能承受乌克兰的失败，但也出于非常可操作的原因。”

;

;博纳被问到中国不应该做哪些事情。他说：“当然要提供武器，还有经济支持。”

;“快跑！”这是给菲律宾人马克斯和简的唯一指示，结束了他们在缅甸长达六个月的强迫网络诈骗的折磨。

;

;获得自由的一天，他们坐在湄索（去年年底他们被贩运经过的同一个泰国边境城镇）郊区的一间农舍里，两人回忆起他们紧张的最后时刻，当时一艘船缓缓穿过一条狭窄的河颈，驶向安全地带。

;

;一旦到达泰国河岸，他们的监护人告诉他们“你需要做的就是”跑吧，”简说——于是他们就这么做了，手里拿着行李。麦克斯仍然对这段经历感到震惊，他让简代表他在《亚洲周刊》上发表讲话。

;

;他们在接到泰国高薪工作的广告后，于 12 月和 1 月分别从菲律宾抵达

;

;但他们却被驱赶到西北近 500 公里的湄索，穿过狭窄的莫埃河进入缅甸，被迫在中国犯罪分子经营的一个大院里诈骗欧洲和北美的目标。

;

;当他们离开时，他们身上都带着伤疤。简说：“我成为了欺骗人们的工具，我为他们工作……即使这不是我自己的选择。”印度、肯尼亚和尼泊尔承诺提供高薪工作，结果却被困在网络诈骗的迷宫中数月或数年。

;

;Jane和Max说，他们被迫工作的“公司”是克伦邦妙瓦底镇40公里长的河流沿岸十几家蓬勃发展的公司之一，这些公司是横跨东南亚的中国主导的庞大诈骗网络的节点。

;

;柬埔寨的诈骗行业去年声名狼藉。在有关大规模人口贩运、强迫劳动和系统性酷刑的报道不断出现之后。 6 月下旬，菲律宾作为主要诈骗中心的角色也得到了重申，当时马尼拉南部的一个中国经营的诈骗中心遭到突袭，释放了 2,700 多人，而老挝则在臭名昭著的金三角经济特区开展了大规模诈骗活动。

;

;但在缅甸，这些残暴的犯罪活动仍然不受制止。他们受到 2021 年军事政变引发的该国持续的国内动乱的怂恿，并由中国犯罪分子和当地准军事组织的联盟操纵，超出了外部执法机构、民间社会和媒体的影响范围。

;

;为了调查这场危机，《亚洲周刊》采访了来自 7 个国家的 18 名前和现任工人，他们今年和去年都被贩运到克伦邦苗瓦底地区，被迫在那里进行诈骗；身体和心理上受到虐待；并阻止其离开。

;

;美国和平研究所 (USIP) 冲突监测机构缅甸国家主任杰森·塔尔 (Jason Tower) 表示，这是“骗局中的联合国”。 “骗子是从所有这些不同的国家作为强迫劳工被贩运来的。”

;

;要进出，大多数人都会通过漏洞百出的泰国和缅甸边境。国际移民组织驻泰国代表团团长杰拉尔丁·安萨特 (Geraldine Ansart) 表示，自 2022 年中期以来，该组织收到了“大量”潜在人口贩运转介。 “我们可以假设这只是冰山一角。”

;

;该行业被认为价值数十亿美元，被盗的资金用于购买虚假网站；招募新受害者的招聘人员；以及为那些渴望工作的人开放边界的腐败官员。

;

;简相信她正在申请亚马逊的工作，这是她之前在菲律宾工作过的一家公司，与看似真实的公司电子邮件地址相对应。她的招聘人员帮她预订了飞往曼谷的航班，几天之内，她就开着车前往河边。

;

;

;

;一个周日的早晨，在莫埃河的泰国河岸上，一群男人放下早餐，一辆卡车驶来，将里面的东西卸下来：一盒盒尿布、巧克力威化饼和几瓶燕窝饮料，装进下面的一艘船上。

;

;其中一些货物将运往河对岸苗瓦迪的一个大院。这些人称这里是一家“中国在线赌博公司”的所在地——这是诈骗活动的委婉说法。

;

;据今年早些时候被困在那里五个月的三名印尼男子称，这个大院被称为“家庭公园”。他们说，里面有大约 2,000 名工人，他们进行网上诈骗，并遭受严重的身体虐待，例如在正午炎热中强行奔跑、殴打和电击。

;

;“有一次，我们 20 个人被锁在一个房间里，每天只能得到一次食物……他们（警卫）过来对我拳打脚踢，触电身亡，并用棍子殴打我，”其中一名男子阿里夫说。

;

;人口贩卖和“爱情诈骗” '：菲律宾一家遭到突袭的中国博彩公司内部

;

;尽管家庭公园仍在扩张，但它在妙瓦底镇众多诈骗中心中只是一个小角色。

;

;随着河流向南弯曲，臭名昭著的 KK 公园区在缅甸河岸上映入眼帘。这是一个由两部分组成的庞大建筑群，其宽大的红色屋顶是诈骗、走私和酷刑的代名词，甚至有关于器官贩运的谣言。

;

;KK Park 发展迅速，Maxar Technologies 提供的卫星图像表明第一阶段（称为 KK I）于 2019 年底至 2021 年中期完成。

;

;它的姊妹院落，称为 KK II（一些受害者称其为“东风”）于 4 月份在一块空地上拔地而起。到 2021 年，今年 3 月将成为一个庞大的网站。该工地目前正在建设一栋大型新建筑。

;

;在 KK I 的一栋四层楼建筑中，Jane 和 Max 被迫充当诈骗者，加入最多 15 人的团队，轮班工作 12 至 14 小时，以实现每天 25,000 美元的目标。

;

;两人表示，他们的办公室里至少还有 300 人，他们被组织起来执行诸如在社交媒体上寻找受害者或“标记”等任务。

;

;Jane 表示，她办公室的团队通常会使用臭名昭著的“杀猪”骗局等技术来达到目标​​，在该骗局中，他们假扮成恋人，引诱目标参与欺诈性投资计划。

;

;“[老板们]认为我们是机器人。你需要为他们提供金钱。你需要向他们提供销售……否则，严厉的惩罚正在等着你。”Jane 指着她背上因殴打而留下的伤疤说道。

;

;在某些日子里，当诈骗进入“杀戮阶段”时，这些团队的收入高达 20 万美元：在最后阶段，包裹在骗局中的标记会注入越来越多的金钱。

;

;

;

;大约 25 公里上方河边坐落着专家们认为是缅甸诈骗交易零地的地方：Shwe Kokko，一座遍布赌场、酒店、KTV 房间和诈骗场所的小城市。

;

;Shwe Kokko 位于克伦邦边防部队控制的地区，该部队是一个准军事组织，名义上由 Saw Chit Thu 上校领导的缅甸军方指挥。

;

;

;该项目被称为 Yatai Shwe Kokko 经济特区，到 2019 年，该项目的发展已远远超出其特许范围。修订后的亚泰洲际酒店集团宣传材料展示了建设一座价值 150 亿美元的闪亮城市的计划，其中包括金融区、工业区和豪华度假村。

;在全国人口危机的讨论中，复旦大学教授表示，中国社会应该适应生育率下降的新常态，认识到生育政策的效果需要时间和探索。

; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 10:20:02 +0800 ‘Baby spicy style’ fashion that parades little girls in tight skirts and low-cut dresses slammed by Chinese state media, derided as ‘pornography’https://www.scmp.com/news/people-culture/gender-diversity/article/3228334/baby-spicy-style-fashion-parades-little-girls-tight-skirts-and-low-cut-dresses-slammed-chinese-state?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.22 09:00;
;;

;The emergence in China of a sexualised children's fashion trend known as “baby spicy style” has created an online furore after mainland state media slammed the phenomenon as “twisted”.

;

;The style, which sees little girls striking sexy poses in low-cut dresses, crop tops and high-waist trousers – scaled down versions of adult women's clothing – has become trendy among children's wear e-commerce shops and parenting influencers in China in recent years.

;

;The term “baby spicy style”, or naila in Mandarin, was invented by followers of the genre to describe the contrasting mixture of children's innocence and the “spicy girl” style of dress.

;

;Chinese official news website People's Daily Online posted a commentary on July 18 condemning it as an “inappropriate and uncomfortable” style that only benefits traffic-chasing merchants and parents but leaves children with “a twisted childhood”.

;

;According to the state-owned newspaper Legal Daily, the criticism came after the parents of a Beijing girl, aged around six to eight, ignored an extracurricular class teacher's advice to change their daughter's “sexy” low-cut dress and black pantyhose on July 10.

;

;The parents' nonchalant attitude reflects the popularity of such fashion in China.

;

;On the Chinese e-commerce platform Taobao, owned by Alibaba which owns the South China Morning Post, a store called Zhiliao Chengzhangji has 443,000 followers with its clothes marketed at girls from toddlers to tweens.

;

;In promotional photos, the store's model, aged around six, sports vampish make-up and sexualised styling while striking poses that highlight her “body curves”.

;

;In another children's wear store with 2.7 million followers, the girl model's face was filtered to give the effect of bigger eyes and a pointy jaw, making her look more like a woman.

;

;Meanwhile, some parenting influencers smelled a business opportunity in dressing up their girls like adult women.

;

;Such influencers on the lifestyle platform Xiaohongshu, mostly mothers, flaunted their daughters' “excellent” physical features – ones normally associated with that of an adult woman – highlighted by the chic clothing, posting comments such as “check out my daughter's long legs” and “she looks so white in the dress”.

;

;One mother said in her daughter's OOTD - outfit of the day - account: “She looks like a doll.”

;

;Dr Paul Wong Wai-ching, associate professor in the department of social work and social administration at the University of Hong Kong, told the Post that the thought of having full control over their children, in particular among Asian parents, violates the value that every human being should be treated as an individual.

;

;The adultification or sexualisation of girls' clothing is not a China-only problem.

;

;In 2011, French designer Sophie Morin faced backlash after her brand, Jours Après Lunes, promoted lingerie for girls aged from four to 12.

;

;A year before that, Australian apparel brand Witchery sparked controversy by featuring children in adult attire and mature poses in its kids' wear look book.

;

;The design of Chinese children's wear also moved from a cartoon style to adultified fashion around the same time.

;

;A 2007 article from 51kids, a Chinese website for children's wear, observed the trend led by several popular overseas brands, such as France's Elle and South Korea's E-Land, which promoted scaled-down versions of adult clothes as part of the parent-child lookalike vogue.

;

;On Weibo, the Chinese equivalent of Twitter, the hashtag “People's Daily Online commenting on baby spicy style” had been viewed 250 million times by the time of writing, reigniting the heated debate over sexualised children's fashion.

;

;“They are making adult wear like kids' wear, and kids' wear like adult wear, I don't understand,” said one observer on Weibo.

;

;“Kids should not be described using words like 'spicy' and 'sexy', let alone being dressed in such clothes,” said another person.

;

;“Every age group has their own beauty, yet females are all dressed like the same age group no matter how old they are,” a third pointed out.

;

;Some, however, supported the trend, insisting that even children should have “freedom to dress”. This viewpoint was in the minority, though.

;

;One person commented: “A child's independent consciousness is still not fully developed for them to know what they like. They should have freedom to dress, but not now.”

;

;Wong said such fashion could have a negative impact on children's development, and may even cause cyberbullying which children are not mature enough to digest.

;

;He added that “baby spicy style” is going too far and is close to child pornography.

;

;Under China's revised Law on the Protection of Minors, which came into effect in 2021, it is illegal to make, copy, publish or possess pornographic content about minors.

;

;However, there is still a lack of laws or industry standards to protect children from fashion styles that jeopardise their physical or mental health, Wang Yawei, an expert in criminal law at Beijing Allwell Law Firm, told Legal Daily.

; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 09:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong’s rural cleaners at mercy of heat while some are unaware of alerts and have nowhere to resthttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3228420/hong-kongs-rural-cleaners-mercy-heat-while-some-are-unaware-alerts-and-have-nowhere-rest?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.22 09:00;
;;

;Hong Kong cleaner Mei* was towing two fully loaded garbage bins to a refuse collection point in Yuen Long, unaware that a heat stress warning had been raised, indicating a high risk of heatstroke for outdoor workers like her.

;

;But she knew it was very hot. “I felt like I was about to get heatstroke,” she said, putting on a makeshift umbrella-like hat for some shade from the sun.

;

;The amber heat stress signal was issued at 8.40am that day, after the temperature soared to 36 degrees Celsius.

;

;Hong Kong bosses in hot seat? New anti-heatstroke guide to protect workers

;

;But Mei did not stop working because, like many outdoor workers in rural areas, there was nowhere to go for some cool respite. Her designated rest area was a public toilet with no drinking water or electricity.

;

;“Sometimes I have to sneak into people's private spaces,” she said.

;

;Under new anti-heatstroke guidelines introduced in mid May, a three-level colour coded warning system – amber, red and black – is triggered when the temperature rises too high. It is based on the Hong Kong Heat Index co-developed by the Observatory and Chinese University.

;

;The Observatory also alerts the public with a very hot weather warning triggered whenever the temperature hits 33 degrees Celsius (91.4 degrees Fahrenheit).

;

;Between May 15 and June 30, there were 23 amber heat stress warnings.

;

;Both the construction and cleaning sectors have criticised the new system, saying it had only caused confusion for outdoor workers.

;

;Under the system, outdoor workers are recommended to take between 15 and 45 minutes of rest per hour at each level, depending on the intensity of their work.

;

;Cleaners, whose work is regarded as “moderately” intense, should take a 15-minute break for each hour of work when the amber warning is raised.

;

;A shield from heatstroke? Hong Kong to include heat index in employers' guide

;

;While cleaners in urban and rural areas complained that they were often not even aware of the heat stress alerts, those in rural areas – mainly in Yuen Long and North districts – said they did not have anywhere to go to take cover from the heat.

;

;The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) said some rural refuse collection points were in remote areas that presented constraints in installing facilities such as electric fans and changing areas.

;

;Hong Kong has 902 village-type refuse collection points, including 178 in Yuen Long and 154 in North districts.

;

;Rural cleaner Hing*, who works with Mei, said her designated rest area was a tiny, windowless trash station without electricity and only a makeshift cover.

;

;Both women were unaware of the heat stress warning at about 9.30am that day. Hing said they did not receive any alert from their cleaning company.

;

;According to Labour Department guidelines, employers may reduce the 15-minute break under the amber code if workers are given equipment to help keep cool, including portable fans.

;

;Mei and Hing were each given a portable waist fan, but they said it was “useless”.

;

;It runs out of battery very quickly. It's very noisy and you need to attach it to your waistband, which is very clumsy,” Hing said.

;

;Hong Kong bosses not warm on new anti-heatstroke guidelines

;

;The Labour Department told the Post that such devices were meant to “decrease heat stress and the rest time required for cooling down”, but said employers had to ensure they worked.

;

;Unionist and lawmaker Lam Chun-sing was concerned that the new guidelines left “wiggle room” for employers to cut rest time.

;

;“We fear that some employers might take advantage of the adjustment, such as casually installing two unusable fans as an excuse to reduce rest time,” he said.

;

;Adjusting the rest time was justifiable only if workers had access to covered areas or cooling systems, he added.

;

;He hoped employers would establish a system to prepare for escalated heat stress warnings that could occur in the coming weeks.

;

;“To reinforce the warning, the authorities can conduct more high profile on-site inspections,” he said.

;

;Hong Kong issues second amber alert under new heat-warning system

;

;The cleaners interviewed by the Post also complained that their new uniforms were made of unbreathable material which did not absorb perspiration and could contribute to heatstroke too.

;

;“Because the uniform doesn't absorb sweat, it runs straight down to my pants,” Mei said.

;

;Lee Mei-siu, vice-chairwoman of the FEHD Staff Rights Union, said frontline cleaners in every district had complained that the uniforms contained too much plastic and caused heat rash.

;

;She said the authorities should not assume that public toilets or other amenities were good enough for workers as these were not designed to be rest areas.

;

;Her union has distributed salt sweets, electrolyte drinks, medicated oil and arm protectors to frontline cleaners, while also educating them on the different levels of heatstroke.

;

;She said the new heat stress system had raised public awareness about the risk of heatstroke among outdoor workers, but it remained “impractical”.

;

;“It cannot fully reflect the actual working environment especially for these rural cleaners,” she said. “Since many cleaners are responsible for managing a village on their own, it can be dangerous if they pass out and no one is around.”

;

;Last year, the Labour Department recorded 18 work injury cases related to heat stress, with one death. Earlier this month, a construction worker died after being found unconscious on scaffolding outside a university building during an amber heat stress warning.

;

;Lee said many cases of heatstroke went unreported because most cleaners' symptoms were not severe enough to require medical attention or sick leave.

;

;“Although finding suitable spots to install facilities is challenging, it is possible as long as you make an effort and conduct on-site visits,” she said.

;

;*Full names withheld at interviewees' request

; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 09:20:02 +0800 ‘Close enough’ isn’t good enough for Hong Kong when it comes to construction safety standardshttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3228324/close-enough-isnt-good-enough-hong-kong-when-it-comes-construction-safety-standards?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.22 08:15;
;;

;More than a hundred years ago, Chinese scholar and educator Hu Shih wrote “The Legend of Mr Close Enough”, which Hong Kong students would likely have read as part of the Chinese language curriculum. At that young age, I did not fully comprehend the story's underlying meaning.

;

;At best, I knew Hu was portraying a lazy person satisfied with his lack of effort in doing anything. He was ridiculing a widespread cultural mentality at a time when the mindset of “almost is good enough” and “do the minimum to get by” was spreading from one person to another.

;

;While there is nothing wrong with being content with one's life and taking things easy, there are times when we carry more responsibility and half-hearted efforts are simply not enough. What I never imagined was that years later when working in the professional world, there would be so many Mr Close Enoughs in the construction industry.

;

;It is not uncommon that before a construction tender is awarded, a tenderer will claim they can deliver all the required work as specified, but everything becomes difficult once the contract is confirmed. At that point, Mr Close Enough makes his appearance.

;

;In a best-case scenario, the contractor tests the owner's bottom line and asks for design and specification changes so the work can be done by easier means. In a worst-case scenario, the contractor fails to follow the requirements while doing the work and doesn't tell anybody.

;

;These contractors' objectives are to provide something close to the specifications by the most economical means, to do the least to get by, and to get it done quickly before it could be rejected. This phenomenon is far from uncommon, with similar challenges emerging in many projects.

;

;We come from an ancient civilisation that invented the dougong nailless construction method and perfected timber framework in imperial palaces and religious temples. Our ancestors could also carve the Jadeite Cabbage, write on a grain of rice and draw inside a snuff bottle. What kind of detailed, quality workmanship can't we accomplish?

;

;We now have better tools, better technology and better guidelines and standards. The problem is not a lack of knowledge, skills or experience. Instead, the problem is in the mentality of Mr Close Enough, who makes an appearance when a contracting company makes promises bigger than it can deliver and comes under pressure from the owners and stakeholders. After all, doing things properly may be more time-consuming and costly.

;

;From the shifting breakwater structure at the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge to the shortened steel bars at the Sha Tin-Central rail link, from the shoddy concrete columns at the University of Hong Kong High West Site to the subpar concrete walls at a private residential development at Tai Wai, we are hearing more about substandard construction projects in recent years.

;

;Hong Kong building defects cost more than reputation

;

;This does not necessarily mean shoddy construction is more common these days, but we now have social media and whistle-blowers to expose scandals and spread word of them faster than anybody could cover up or defuse them. Thanks to the conventionally high safety factor in structural design, structures rarely fail even if they are not built exactly to specifications, but that does not mean they are tolerable by industry standards.

;

;There is little incentive for owners or developers to let contractors take their time to finish their work in a capitalist society. However, the quality of the work is also important. This is why good project planning, prudent management, and diligent supervision matter. A successful project demands balancing competing interests – the owner's time and money versus the contractor's required resources to deliver the project as intended.

;

;Good management also means that when problems arise – which is almost certain to happen on any construction site – sound, timely decisions are taken to rectify them. This way, we do not continue to pursue the wrong path or fall for the “sunk cost” fallacy, carrying on even when knowingly dealing with a lost cause.

;

;If we do not, the consequences could be severe, as in the HK$2 billion (US$256 million) in extra costs for the Sha Tin-Central rail link. In an extreme example, New World Development decided to tear down and rebuild multiple towers in its Tai Wai residential project while compensating buyers for their losses, losing HK$6.6 billion in market value in the process.

;

;We cannot let the Mr Close Enoughs of the world get away unscathed when it comes to matters of safety standards. The HK$40,000 fine Leighton Contractors received for its work at Hung Hom MTR station as part of the Sha Tin-Central rail link project was nothing more than a slap on the wrist.

;

;Instead, we should consider much more substantial punishment – such as a sizeable monetary fine, long-term registration suspension or criminal indictment – to make sure similar incidents do no occur again in any public or private projects. This is a long-overdue opportunity for the government to banish a harmful cultural mindset in the construction industry and make a profound statement that “close enough” is simply not good enough.

;US President Joe Biden said on Friday that new commitments by Amazon, Google, Meta, Microsoft and other companies that are leading the development of artificial intelligence technology to meet a set of AI safeguards brokered by his White House are an important step toward managing the “enormous” promise and risks posed by the technology.

;

;Biden announced that his administration has secured voluntary commitments from seven US companies meant to ensure their AI products are safe before they release them.

;

;Some of the commitments call for third-party oversight of the workings of commercial AI systems, though they do not detail who will audit the technology or hold the companies accountable.

;

;“We must be clear eyed and vigilant about the threats emerging technologies can pose,” Biden said, adding that the companies have a “fundamental obligation” to ensure their products are safe.

;

;“Social media has shown us the harm that powerful technology can do without the right safeguards in place,” Biden added. “These commitments are a promising step, but we have a lot more work to do together.”

;

;A surge of commercial investment in generative AI tools that can write convincingly humanlike text and churn out new images and other media has brought public fascination as well as concern about their ability to trick people and spread disinformation, among other dangers.

;

;The four tech giants, along with ChatGPT-maker OpenAI and start-ups Anthropic and Inflection, have committed to security testing “carried out in part by independent experts” to guard against major risks, such as to biosecurity and cybersecurity, the White House said in a statement.

;

;That testing will also examine the potential for societal harms, such as bias and discrimination, and more theoretical dangers about advanced AI systems that could gain control of physical systems or “self-replicate” by making copies of themselves.

;

;AI poses 'extinction' risk comparable to nuclear war, pandemics: experts

;

;The companies have also committed to methods for reporting vulnerabilities to their systems and to using digital watermarking to help distinguish between real and AI-generated images known as deepfakes.

;

;They will also publicly report flaws and risks in their technology, including effects on fairness and bias, the White House said.

;

;The voluntary commitments are meant to be an immediate way of addressing risks ahead of a longer-term push to get Congress to pass laws regulating the technology. Company executives plan to gather with Biden at the White House on Friday as they pledge to follow the standards.

;

;Some advocates for AI regulations said Biden's move is a start but more needs to be done to hold the companies and their products accountable.

;

;“A closed-door deliberation with corporate actors resulting in voluntary safeguards isn't enough,” said Amba Kak, executive director of the AI Now Institute.

;

;“We need a much more wide-ranging public deliberation, and that's going to bring up issues that companies almost certainly won't voluntarily commit to because it would lead to substantively different results, ones that may more directly impact their business models.”

;

;Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer has said he will introduce legislation to regulate AI. He said in a statement that he will work closely with the Biden administration “and our bipartisan colleagues” to build upon the pledges made on Friday.

;

;A number of technology executives have called for regulation, and several went to the White House in May to speak with Biden, Vice-President Kamala Harris and other officials.

;

;UK turns to AI to disrupt weapon flow to Russia, says spy chief

;

;Microsoft President Brad Smith said in a blog post on Friday that his company is making some commitments that go beyond the White House pledge, including support for regulation that would create a “licensing regime for highly capable models”.

;

;But some experts and upstart competitors worry that the type of regulation being floated could be a boon for deep-pocketed first-movers led by OpenAI, Google and Microsoft as smaller players are elbowed out by the high cost of making their AI systems, known as large language models, adhere to regulatory strictures.

;

;The White House pledge notes that it mostly only applies to models that “are overall more powerful than the current industry frontier”, set by currently available models such as OpenAI's GPT-4 and image generator DALL-E 2 and similar releases from Anthropic, Google and Amazon.

;

;A number of countries have been looking at ways to regulate AI, including European Union lawmakers who have been negotiating sweeping AI rules for the 27-nation bloc that could restrict applications deemed to have the highest risks.

;

;UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres recently said the United Nations is “the ideal place” to adopt global standards and appointed a board that will report back on options for global AI governance by the end of the year.

;

;Guterres also said he welcomed calls from some countries for the creation of a new UN body to support global efforts to govern AI, inspired by such models as the International Atomic Energy Agency or the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

;

;The White House said on Friday that it has already consulted on the voluntary commitments with a number of countries.

;

;The pledge is heavily focused on safety risks but does not address other worries about the latest AI technology, including the effect on jobs and market competition, the environmental resources required to build the models, and copyright concerns about the writings, art and other human handiwork being used to teach AI systems how to produce humanlike content.

;

;Last week, OpenAI and Associated Press announced a deal for the AI company to license AP's archive of news stories. The amount it will pay for that content was not disclosed.

;A probe initiated by a US congressional panel into four American venture capital firms for their investment in Chinese tech firms could send jitters through US-dollar funds in China, analysts said.

;

;The inquiry letters sent by the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party notified GGV Capital, GSR Ventures, Qualcomm Ventures and Walden International of scrutiny into their backing of Chinese start-ups in areas including artificial intelligence (AI), semiconductors and quantum computing. The move is set to deal a fresh blow to the struggling US dollar-denominated funds, which had benefited the rise of many tech firms in the country over the last two decades.

;

;The inquiry comes as US venture capital is drying up for Chinese start-ups, especially those working in AI and semiconductors, amid escalating geopolitical tensions between Beijing and Washington. There have been only 1,645 investment deals involving US-dollar funds in China so far this year, for an average of 235 per month, according to local start-up data service Itjuzi.com. That is a significant drop from last year's 4,751 deals, or about 396 per month.

;

;Why this venture investor is bullish on Chinese AI despite US chip curbs

;

;The move “will add another layer of challenges for US VC firms looking to be active in China's VC market”, Kyle Stanford and Kaidi Gao, VC analysts at investment research firm Pitchbook, told the Post via email on Thursday.

;

;They added that US-invested deals into China will shrink further as acrimony rises between the two countries. “Some US VC funds that historically had heavy China exposure have been re-evaluating their China strategy during the past few quarters,” they said.

;

;Reva Goujon, director of China corporate advisory at independent research firm Rhodium Group, told the Post that the probe will have a wider impact on US firms' investment practices in China.

;

;While the panel does not have legislative authority, it has the subpoena power to put these firms in the regulatory spotlight, and “the public and political scrutiny can then inform the scope and design of the outbound investment measures”, Goujon added.

;

;One executive in the Chinese venture capital industry, who declined to be named because of the sensitivity of the topic, said Chinese start-ups in the so-called “hard tech” fields are also increasingly reluctant to take money from US investors given Beijing's rising scrutiny of such deals.

;

;According to his discussions with Chinese start-ups, the person said these companies are unlikely to take US dollars from American investors, but they may use the currency if it is coming from somewhere else, such as the Middle East.

;

;The Pitchbook analysts also ascribed low US-firm activity in AI and semiconductors to restrictions from both China and the US.

;

;“From the Chinese side, it remains unclear whether the Chinese government is committed to supporting overseas (especially US) investment in a way that helps ensure return potential for those investors,” they said.

;

;The result of the years-long US-China tech war is a slow divorce between US venture capital funds and China tech start-ups. Sequoia Capital, which was not among the firms being probed, announced last month that it would split itself into three independent entities, with Sequoia China renamed HongShan.

;

;Michael Gallagher, the Republican chair of the US House committee, said the four US venture capital firms are “initial targets”, hinting that the scope of the probe could expand.

;

;US House panel scrutinises VC investments into Chinese AI and semiconductors

;

;GSR Ventures, which according to the Centre for Security and Emerging Technology has at least 33 investments in Chinese AI firms, was among the top US-located investors funding China's AI advancement, the congressional panel said.

;

;GGV Capital conducted 43 transactions funding Chinese AI firms from 2015 to 2021, according to the panel.

;

;The letters also mentioned investments into specific companies, including SenseTime, which received funding from Qualcomm Ventures. The letter to the chip giant's investment arm cited reports that the company is involved in surveillance of the Uygur ethnic minority in the western region of Xinjiang.

;

;A representative for the Shanghai-based AI company said the accusations – which Washington used as grounds for blacklisting the firm in 2019 – are “unfounded and reflect a fundamental misperception”.

;

;The four US investment firms did not immediately respond to requests for comment on Thursday.

;

;Other Chinese companies mentioned in the panel's letters – including AI and robotics companies Zongmu Technology and Denglin Technology, chip makers Cygnus Semi, Moore Threads, Horizon Robotics, Biren Technology and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation (SMIC) – also did not respond to requests for comment. Gantu AI, a Shanghai-based computer vision technology developer, declined to comment.

;Two Indonesian women have apologised after a lavish “wedding” for their dogs sparked a backlash in the middle-income country, where wealth distribution is one of the most unequal in the world.

;

;Two Alaskan Malamutes were wedded at a mall in the capital Jakarta, donning traditional Javanese outfits alongside their owners and relatives at a fake ceremony that reportedly cost 200 million rupiah (US$13,300).

;

;A social media uproar followed after images emerged of the wolf-like dogs taking each other's paws in marriage at the extravagant ceremony, forcing the owners into a contrite news conference.

;

;“We regret it very much and we would like to apologise for the Javanese culture enthusiasts and all Indonesians who were uncomfortable and hurt by the event,” said Indira Ratnasari, owner of female dog Luna.

;

;“We had no intention to insult the Indonesian and the Javanese culture,” she said, according to footage posted on her makeup artist's Instagram account.

;

;Ostentatious displays of wealth in the world's fourth-most populous country are frowned upon and often criticised because of its widening income gap.

;

;The minimum monthly wage in Jakarta is 4.9 million rupiah (US$325) and the World Bank last year said nearly a tenth of Indonesia's 270 million people still live below the poverty line.

;

;Ratnasari is on the payroll of the Indonesian presidential office, local media reported.

;

;Indonesia Muslim groups 'concerned' over Jokowi's Iftar ban for officials

;

;Indonesian President Joko Widodo told public officials in a March speech not to flaunt their extravagant lives in “improper” ways, including social media posts.

;

;Valentine Cahandra, owner of male dog Jojo, claimed the wedding took place to promote Javanese culture.

;

;But angry Indonesians took to social media to condemn the expensive canine nuptials.

;

;“It's wasting money and defying God. Common sense has gone, trampled by the desire to show off,” one Twitter user posted.

;

;Another wrote: “Unnecessarily wasting their wealth, they should have helped people in need instead.”

;

;“Is this what we call 'social blindness'?”
